abstract: Genetic analysis of British population led by Drs Stephen Leslie, Peter Donnelly and Walter Bodmer published in journal Nature reveals extensive mixing of genetics of Romano-British people and invading Angles and Saxon in southern and central England, leading to largely homogenous population; also reveals surprising number of genetically unique populations around Britain's Celtic periphery, pointing to influence of Roman rule on genetic variation.
lead_paragraph: Researchers found that the modern British population falls into 17 clusters that are all very similar but genetically distinguishable.

headline.main: Study Reveals Genetic Path of Modern Britons
headline.print_headline: Genetics Team Provides Answers About Origins of Modern Britons

snippet: Researchers found that the modern British population falls into 17 clusters that are all very similar but genetically distinguishable.
